commits.message:
Cleanup Python 2 compact from Lexers (#14190)

Python 2 has reached end of life and its support has been dropped
already. This patch removes the lexer dedicated to Python 2.

Fixes #14021

issue.title: Cleanup Python 2 compact from IPython/lib/lexers.py
issue.body: There should still be Python 2 lexers that are not useful

issue.title: Support Walrus without parentheses
issue.body:
A pattern we use commonly in our notebooks (which are often used for documentation - [e.g.](https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/data)) is:

```python
something = create_the_thing()
something
<displays {something}>
```

With the Walrus operator ([`:=`](https://peps.python.org/pep-0572/)), we are able to indicate that we want to both assign and return in one statement, so the above cell can be replaced with:

```python
(something := create_the_thing())
<displays {something}>
```

This works, but we are required to wrap the whole line in parentheses as Python does not support a bare walrus - it is only considered valid syntax when the walrus is wrapped in a parenthetical blanket.

This FR is to request support for a "bare walrus" statement, so that this works:

```python
something := create_the_thing()
<displays {something}>
```

comment.body:
> This would likely need a change in cpython so that we can at least parse it.

This implicitely mean that I would appreciate if anyone woudl challenge this upstream. 
We did get the [PyCF_ALLOW_TOP_LEVEL_AWAIT](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#compile) in Python 3.8 so a new flag that let compile top level walrus woudl be nice. 

@lysnikolaou you are working on having a better REPL for CPython, I think this woudl count.

issue.title: Support Walrus without parentheses
issue.body:
A pattern we use commonly in our notebooks (which are often used for documentation - [e.g.](https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/data)) is:

```python
something = create_the_thing()
something
<displays {something}>
```

With the Walrus operator ([`:=`](https://peps.python.org/pep-0572/)), we are able to indicate that we want to both assign and return in one statement, so the above cell can be replaced with:

```python
(something := create_the_thing())
<displays {something}>
```

This works, but we are required to wrap the whole line in parentheses as Python does not support a bare walrus - it is only considered valid syntax when the walrus is wrapped in a parenthetical blanket.

This FR is to request support for a "bare walrus" statement, so that this works:

```python
something := create_the_thing()
<displays {something}>
```

comment.body:
This would likely need a change in cpython so that we can at least parse it.

In the man time you can just use the IPython option to do that by default with `=` ?

```
In [13]: config InteractiveShell.ast_node_interactivity='last_expr_or_assign'

In [14]: a = 1
Out[14]: 1
```

issue.title: “ TypeError: 'ExtendedCompletionFinder' object is not callable” I ran into this problem when running ipython in a virtual environment, how do I solve it?
issue.body:
<!-- This is the repository for IPython command line, if you can try to make sure this question/bug/feature belong here and not on one of the Jupyter repositories. 

If it's a generic Python/Jupyter question, try other forums or discourse.jupyter.org.

If you are unsure, it's ok to post here, though, there are few maintainer so you might not get a fast response. 

-->

comment.body: Try to upgrade or downgrade the `triatlets` package, and see if that works.

So please double check if it still works the same way as before.

issue.title: Docs Version8 Typo
issue.body:
[This page of the docs](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/2c4c28a3aa290f38bf58710a045bdbda5e59e196/docs/source/whatsnew/version8.rst) says 'woth' instead of 'with'

Tried opening a PR myself but don't have permission so felt obligated to raise this somewhere.

Hope this helps!

comment.body: Looks like it is already fixed in commit 0cef1d9739a5a5c56c526f394bde7999a485bff3

issue.title: Change in default behaviour of Ctrl + up in 8.14.0

labels.name: autosuggestions
labels.description: Related to fish-like autosuggestion feature (as opposed to the tab-completions)

issue.body:
> it seems that 8.14.0 restored the default up/down navigation, but instead broke the ctrl+up/down navigation.
> 
> For example, consider the following inputs:
> 
> ```python
> In [1]: a = [
>    ...:     "this is",
>    ...:     "a list",
>    ...: ]
> 
> In [2]: a = """
>    ...: this is a
>    ...: multiline string
>    ...: """
> 
> In [3]: a = <cursor>
> ```
> 
> In `ipython<8.9` you could press `ctrl+up ctrl+up` to get the list.
> 
> In `ipython==8.14.0`  it seems that `ctrl+up` cycles through the "ghost" > autocompletions, so `ctrl+up ctrl+up` cycles between the fake `"""` and `[` postfixes. `up > ctrl+up` doesn't work either, because `ctrl+up` just moves the cursor up one line > instead of selecting the previous cell.

_Originally posted by @RuRo in https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/13993#issuecomment-1591618078_

comment.body: well, i agree to @RuRo's point that it's difficult to get over the muscle memory built over the years.. so, it's gonna be [ptipython](https://github.com/prompt-toolkit/ptpython/tree/master#ipython-support) for now...

issue.title: IPython does not start on WSL
issue.body:
I installed IPython on WSL, but when I try to launch it, I get the following error:

```
/mnt/c/Users/User/Desktop$ ipython
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/user/.local/bin/ipython", line 8, in <module>
    sys.exit(start_ipython())
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/IPython/__init__.py", line 129, in start_ipython
    return launch_new_instance(argv=argv, **kwargs)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/traitlets/config/application.py", line 1042, in launch_instance
    app.initialize(argv)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/traitlets/config/application.py", line 113, in inner
    return method(app, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/IPython/terminal/ipapp.py", line 279, in initialize
    self.init_shell()
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/IPython/terminal/ipapp.py", line 293, in init_shell
    self.shell = self.interactive_shell_class.instance(parent=self,
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/traitlets/config/configurable.py", line 551, in instance
    inst = cls(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/IPython/terminal/interactiveshell.py", line 854, in __init__
    super(TerminalInteractiveShell, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/IPython/core/interactiveshell.py", line 575, in __init__
    self.init_virtualenv()
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/IPython/core/interactiveshell.py", line 864, in init_virtualenv
    if p_venv.parts[1] == "cygdrive":
IndexError: tuple index out of range

If you suspect this is an IPython 8.14.0 bug, please report it at:
    https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues
or send an email to the mailing list at ipython-dev@python.org

You can print a more detailed traceback right now with "%tb", or use "%debug"
to interactively debug it.

Extra-detailed tracebacks for bug-reporting purposes can be enabled via:
    c.Application.verbose_crash=True
```

System info:
```
/mnt/c/Users/User/Desktop$ python3 -c "import IPython; print(IPython.sys_info())"
{'commit_hash': 'f11276427',
 'commit_source': 'installation',
 'default_encoding': 'utf-8',
 'ipython_path': '/home/user/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/IPython',
 'ipython_version': '8.14.0',
 'os_name': 'posix',
 'platform': 'Linux-5.15.90.1-microsoft-standard-WSL2-x86_64-with-glibc2.35',
 'sys_executable': '/usr/bin/python3',
 'sys_platform': 'linux',
 'sys_version': '3.10.6 (main, May 29 2023, 11:10:38) [GCC 11.3.0]'}
```

comment.body:
> I received this same error while installing iPython on a Dockerfile. If you look into the source code, `p_env` is a Pathlib object for your `VIRTUAL_ENV` environment variable. For me, the error was resolved by adding a "/" to the forefront of that environment variable.

Can you give me more details? I'm also having the same problem, with a Dockerfile. Can you paste what that part of your Dockerfile was before and after? This has been driving me nuts!

commits.message:
Attempt to remove backcall.

This was meant to allow this API to evolve, but I have the impression
was not use much.

This will reduce our dependencies and reliance on older packages.
